It states:

**a² + b² = c²**

where a and b are the lengths of the legs of a right-angled triangle (i.e., a triangle with one angle being 90 degrees), and c is the length of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle).
It's a powerful tool for calculating distances and lengths in two-dimensional spaces.
It's a gem of a theorem that sheds light on the relationships between the lengths of the sides of triangles, for solving various problems.

The Pythagorean Theorem states that for any right-angled triangle with perpendicular sides of length a and b, (forming a 90-degree angle) and a hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) of length c:

a² + b² = c²

This theorem holds true for all right triangles,1⃣p and allows us to calculate lengths, especially the third side (hypotenuse), given the other two.
